question: What unique vision ability do boas and pythons possess?

options.d: Both through its nose and its tongues

question: Where are Jacobson's organs located in snakes?

question: What substance covers a snake's skin?
What snake doesn't have to have a mate to lay eggs?
Though invasive species can now be found in the Everglades, in which three continents are pythons (members of the family Pythonidae) found in the wild?
Pythons are held as some of the most dangerous snakes on earth, but are often confused with anacondas. Which of these is *not* a difference between pythons and anacondas?

options.a: Pythons suffocate their prey, anacondas crush them
options.b: Pythons lay eggs, anacondas give birth to live young
options.c: Pythons grow longer, anacondas grow heavier
options.d: Pythons generally spend less time in water than anacondas do

question: Pythons are unable to chew their food, and so swallow prey whole. Which of these methods is most commonly demonstrated to help a python to swallow large prey?

options.a: The python's stomach pressure is reduced, so prey is sucked in
options.b: An extra set of upper teeth 'walk' along the prey
options.c: The python holds its head up, so prey falls into its stomach
options.d: Prey is pushed against a barrier and is forced down the python's throat

question: Pythons, like many large constrictors, possess vestigial hind limbs. Whilst these 'spurs' serve no purpose in locomotion, how are they put to use by some male pythons?
Pythons tend to travel by the rectilinear method (in straight lines) when on land, as opposed to the concertina method (s-shaped movement). Why do large pythons tend not to use the concertina method?

options.c: The scales on their backs are too rigid
